body_markdown:
Tried digging through CloudTrail to see if these events could be used as CloudWatch Event Triggers.  Unfortunately, it doesn't seem that `DeleteUser` or `AdminDeleteUser` events are sent to cloudtrail: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cognito/latest/developerguide/logging-using-cloudtrail.html

However, if your app is logging to CloudWatch, you might be able to insert your own events for triggering.
body: Tried digging through CloudTrail to see if these events could be used as CloudWatch Event Triggers. Unfortunately, it doesn't seem that DeleteUser or AdminDeleteUser events are sent to cloudtrail: docs.aws.amazon.com/cognito/latest/developerguide/… However, if your app is logging to CloudWatch, you might be able to insert your own events for triggering.

body_markdown: Well, for my use case I do not call lambda functions from my code. If I had to do that, I also would require an API Gateway etc. just for a single case which is not so frequent. Appreciate your suggestion, but it's far costly and spaghetti for me now.
body: Well, for my use case I do not call lambda functions from my code. If I had to do that, I also would require an API Gateway etc. just for a single case which is not so frequent. Appreciate your suggestion, but it's far costly and spaghetti for me now.

body_markdown: Since JMESPath is evaluated against JSON data, please write the `Tags` line in JSON format, not Python. That is: `{"Tags": [{"Value": "application-server-ab3634b34364a-2", "Key": "Name"}, {"Value": "production", "Key": "Group"}]}`
body: Since JMESPath is evaluated against JSON data, please write the Tags line in JSON format, not Python. That is: {"Tags": [{"Value": "application-server-ab3634b34364a-2", "Key": "Name"}, {"Value": "production", "Key": "Group"}]}

body_markdown: I do not have an out of box solution in mind. As a workaround, can you update your application code to trigger a lambda function whenever the application invokes the "DeleteUser"[1] or "AdminDeleteUser"[2] APIs? [1] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cognito-user-identity-pools/latest/APIReference/API_DeleteUser.html , [2] https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cognito-user-identity-pools/latest/APIReference/API_AdminDeleteUser.html
body: I do not have an out of box solution in mind. As a workaround, can you update your application code to trigger a lambda function whenever the application invokes the "DeleteUser"[1] or "AdminDeleteUser"[2] APIs? [1] docs.aws.amazon.com/cognito-user-identity-pools/latest/… , [2] docs.aws.amazon.com/cognito-user-identity-pools/latest/…

body_markdown: you can call abort from onClick function of button, its fine; the point is that you cannot call abort from your bucket variable as its instance of S3 class and this is not defined. so you need to have an object from bucket.upload(...) on which you can apply the abort method
body: you can call abort from onClick function of button, its fine; the point is that you cannot call abort from your bucket variable as its instance of S3 class and this is not defined. so you need to have an object from bucket.upload(...) on which you can apply the abort method
